text: II
text_tokenized: II

text: No misfortune occurred , again to prevent the ball .
text_tokenized: No misfortune occurred , again to prevent the ball .

text: The day approached , the day arrived ; and after a morning of some anxious watching , Frank Churchill , in all the certainty of his own self , reached Randalls before dinner , and every thing was safe .
text_tokenized: The day approached , the day arrived ; and after a morning of some anxious watching , Frank Churchill , in all the certainty of his own self , reached Randalls before dinner , and every thing was safe .

text: No second meeting had there yet been between him and Emma .
text_tokenized: No second meeting had there yet been between him and Emma .

text: The room at the Crown was to witness it;--but it would be better than a common meeting in a crowd .
text_tokenized: The room at the Crown was to witness it;--but it would be better than a common meeting in a crowd .

text: Mr. Weston had been so very earnest in his entreaties for her arriving there as soon as possible after themselves , for the purpose of taking her opinion as to the propriety and comfort of the rooms before any other persons came , that she could not refuse him , and must therefore spend some quiet interval in the young man 's company . She was to convey Harriet , and they drove to the Crown in good time , the Randalls party just sufficiently before them .
text_tokenized: Mr. Weston had been so very earnest in his entreaties for her arriving there as soon as possible after themselves , for the purpose of taking her opinion as to the propriety and comfort of the rooms before any other persons came , that she could not refuse him , and must therefore spend some quiet interval in the young man 's company . She was to convey Harriet , and they drove to the Crown in good time , the Randalls party just sufficiently before them .

text: Frank Churchill seemed to have been on the watch ; and though he did not say much , his eyes declared that he meant to have a delightful evening .
text_tokenized: Frank Churchill seemed to have been on the watch ; and though he did not say much , his eyes declared that he meant to have a delightful evening .

text: They all walked about together , to see that every thing was as it should be ; and within a few minutes were joined by the contents of another carriage , which Emma could not hear the sound of at first , without great surprize .
text_tokenized: They all walked about together , to see that every thing was as it should be ; and within a few minutes were joined by the contents of another carriage , which Emma could not hear the sound of at first , without great surprize .

text: " So unreasonably early ! " she was going to exclaim ; but she presently found that it was a family of old friends , who were coming , like herself , by particular desire , to help Mr. Weston 's judgment ; and they were so very closely followed by another carriage of cousins , who had been entreated to come early with the same distinguishing earnestness , on the same errand , that it seemed as if half the company might soon be collected together for the purpose of preparatory inspection .
text_tokenized: " So unreasonably early ! " she was going to exclaim ; but she presently found that it was a family of old friends , who were coming , like herself , by particular desire , to help Mr. Weston 's judgment ; and they were so very closely followed by another carriage of cousins , who had been entreated to come early with the same distinguishing earnestness , on the same errand , that it seemed as if half the company might soon be collected together for the purpose of preparatory inspection .

text: Emma perceived that her taste was not the only taste on which Mr. Weston depended , and felt , that to be the favourite and intimate of a man who had so many intimates and confidantes , was not the very first distinction in the scale of vanity .
text_tokenized: Emma perceived that her taste was not the only taste on which Mr. Weston depended , and felt , that to be the favourite and intimate of a man who had so many intimates and confidantes , was not the very first distinction in the scale of vanity .

text: She liked his open manners , but a little less of open - heartedness would have made him a higher character.--General benevolence , but not general friendship , made a man what he ought to be.-- She could fancy such a man . The whole party walked about , and looked , and praised again ; and then , having nothing else to do , formed a sort of half - circle round the fire , to observe in their various modes , till other subjects were started , that , though _ May _ , a fire in the evening was still very pleasant .
text_tokenized: She liked his open manners , but a little less of open - heartedness would have made him a higher character.--General benevolence , but not general friendship , made a man what he ought to be.-- She could fancy such a man . text: Emma found that it was not Mr. Weston 's fault that the number of privy councillors was not yet larger .
text_tokenized: Emma found that it was not Mr. Weston 's fault that the number of privy councillors was not yet larger .

text: They had stopped at Mrs. Bates 's door to offer the use of their carriage , but the aunt and niece were to be brought by the Eltons .
text_tokenized: They had stopped at Mrs. Bates 's door to offer the use of their carriage , but the aunt and niece were to be brought by the Eltons .

text: Frank was standing by her , but not steadily ; there was a restlessness , which shewed a mind not at ease . He was looking about , he was going to the door , he was watching for the sound of other carriages,-- impatient to begin , or afraid of being always near her .
text_tokenized: Frank was standing by her , but not steadily ; there was a restlessness , which shewed a mind not at ease . He was looking about , he was going to the door , he was watching for the sound of other carriages,-- impatient to begin , or afraid of being always near her .

text: Mrs. Elton was spoken of .
text_tokenized: Mrs. Elton was spoken of .

text: " I think she must be here soon , " said he .
text_tokenized: " I think she must be here soon , " said he .

text: " I have a great curiosity to see Mrs. Elton , I have heard so much of her .
text_tokenized: " I have a great curiosity to see Mrs. Elton , I have heard so much of her .

text: It can not be long , I think , before she comes . "
text_tokenized: It can not be long , I think , before she comes . "

text: A carriage was heard .
text_tokenized: A carriage was heard .

text: He was on the move immediately ; but coming back , said , " I am forgetting that I am not acquainted with her .
text_tokenized: He was on the move immediately ; but coming back , said , " I am forgetting that I am not acquainted with her .

text: I have never seen either Mr. or Mrs. Elton .
text_tokenized: I have never seen either Mr. or Mrs. Elton .

text: I have no business to put myself forward . " Mr. and Mrs. Elton appeared ; and all the smiles and the proprieties passed .
text_tokenized: I have no business to put myself forward . " Mr. and Mrs. Elton appeared ; and all the smiles and the proprieties passed .

text: " But Miss Bates and Miss Fairfax ! " said Mr. Weston , looking about .
text_tokenized: " But Miss Bates and Miss Fairfax ! " said Mr. Weston , looking about .

text: " We thought you were to bring them . " The mistake had been slight .
text_tokenized: " We thought you were to bring them . " The mistake had been slight .

text: The carriage was sent for them now .
text_tokenized: The carriage was sent for them now .

text: Emma longed to know what Frank 's first opinion of Mrs. Elton might be ; how he was affected by the studied elegance of her dress , and her smiles of graciousness . He was immediately qualifying himself to form an opinion , by giving her very proper attention , after the introduction had passed .
text_tokenized: Emma longed to know what Frank 's first opinion of Mrs. Elton might be ; how he was affected by the studied elegance of her dress , and her smiles of graciousness . He was immediately qualifying himself to form an opinion , by giving her very proper attention , after the introduction had passed .

text: In a few minutes the carriage returned.--Somebody talked of rain.-- " I will see that there are umbrellas , sir , " said Frank to his father : " Miss Bates must not be forgotten : " and away he went .
text_tokenized: In a few minutes the carriage returned.--Somebody talked of rain.-- " I will see that there are umbrellas , sir , " said Frank to his father : " Miss Bates must not be forgotten : " and away he went .

text: Mr. Weston was following ; but Mrs. Elton detained him , to gratify him by her opinion of his son ; and so briskly did she begin , that the young man himself , though by no means moving slowly , could hardly be out of hearing .
text_tokenized: Mr. Weston was following ; but Mrs. Elton detained him , to gratify him by her opinion of his son ; and so briskly did she begin , that the young man himself , though by no means moving slowly , could hardly be out of hearing .

text: " A very fine young man indeed , Mr. Weston .
text_tokenized: " A very fine young man indeed , Mr. Weston .

text: You know I candidly told you I should form my own opinion ; and I am happy to say that I am extremely pleased with him.--You
text_tokenized: You know I candidly told you I should form my own opinion ; and I am happy to say that I am extremely pleased with him.--You

text: may believe me .
text_tokenized: may believe me .

text: I never compliment .
text_tokenized: I never compliment .

text: I think him a very handsome young man , and his manners are precisely what I like and approve -- so truly the gentleman , without the least conceit or puppyism .
text_tokenized: I think him a very handsome young man , and his manners are precisely what I like and approve -- so truly the gentleman , without the least conceit or puppyism .

text: You must know I have a vast dislike to puppies-- quite a horror of them .
text_tokenized: You must know I have a vast dislike to puppies-- quite a horror of them .

text: They were never tolerated at Maple Grove .
text_tokenized: They were never tolerated at Maple Grove .

text: Neither Mr. Suckling nor me had ever any patience with them ; and we used sometimes to say very cutting things !
text_tokenized: Neither Mr. Suckling nor me had ever any patience with them ; and we used sometimes to say very cutting things !

text: Selina , who is mild almost to a fault , bore with them much better . " While she talked of his son , Mr. Weston 's attention was chained ; but when she got to Maple Grove , he could recollect that there were ladies just arriving to be attended to , and with happy smiles must hurry away .
text_tokenized: Selina , who is mild almost to a fault , bore with them much better . " While she talked of his son , Mr. Weston 's attention was chained ; but when she got to Maple Grove , he could recollect that there were ladies just arriving to be attended to , and with happy smiles must hurry away .

text: Mrs. Elton turned to Mrs. Weston .
text_tokenized: Mrs. Elton turned to Mrs. Weston .

text: " I have no doubt of its being our carriage with Miss Bates and Jane .
text_tokenized: " I have no doubt of its being our carriage with Miss Bates and Jane .

text: Our coachman and horses are so extremely expeditious!--I believe we drive faster than any body.-- What a pleasure it is to send one 's carriage for a friend!-- I understand you were so kind as to offer , but another time it will be quite unnecessary .
text_tokenized: Our coachman and horses are so extremely expeditious!--I believe we drive faster than any body.-- What a pleasure it is to send one 's carriage for a friend!-- I understand you were so kind as to offer , but another time it will be quite unnecessary .

text: You may be very sure I shall always take care of _ them _ . "
text_tokenized: You may be very sure I shall always take care of _ them _ . "

text: Miss Bates and Miss Fairfax , escorted by the two gentlemen , walked into the room ; and Mrs. Elton seemed to think it as much her duty as Mrs. Weston 's to receive them .
text_tokenized: Miss Bates and Miss Fairfax , escorted by the two gentlemen , walked into the room ; and Mrs. Elton seemed to think it as much her duty as Mrs. Weston 's to receive them .

text: Her gestures and movements might be understood by any one who looked on like Emma ; but her words , every body 's words , were soon lost under the incessant flow of Miss Bates , who came in talking , and had not finished her speech under many minutes after her being admitted into the circle at the fire . As the door opened she was heard , " So very obliging of you!--No rain at all .

As the door opened she was heard , " So very obliging of you!--No rain at all .

text: Nothing to signify .
text_tokenized: Nothing to signify .

text: I do not care for myself .
text_tokenized: I do not care for myself .

text: Quite thick shoes .
text_tokenized: Quite thick shoes .

text: And Jane declares-- Well!--(as soon as she was within the door ) Well !
text_tokenized: And Jane declares-- Well!--(as soon as she was within the door ) Well !

text: This is brilliant indeed!--This is admirable!--Excellently contrived , upon my word .
text_tokenized: This is brilliant indeed!--This is admirable!--Excellently contrived , upon my word .

text: Nothing wanting . Could not have imagined it.--So well lighted up!-- Jane , Jane , look!--did you ever see any thing ?
text_tokenized: Nothing wanting . Could not have imagined it.--So well lighted up!-- Jane , Jane , look!--did you ever see any thing ?

text: Oh !
text_tokenized: Oh !

text: Mr. Weston , you must really have had Aladdin 's lamp .
text_tokenized: Mr. Weston , you must really have had Aladdin 's lamp .

text: Good Mrs. Stokes would not know her own room again .
text_tokenized: Good Mrs. Stokes would not know her own room again .

text: I saw her as I came in ; she was standing in the entrance .
text_tokenized: I saw her as I came in ; she was standing in the entrance .

text: ` Oh ! Mrs. Stokes , ' said I-- but I had not time for more . "
text_tokenized: ` Oh ! Mrs. Stokes , ' said I-- but I had not time for more . "

text: She was now met by Mrs. Weston.-- " Very well , I thank you , ma'am .
text_tokenized: She was now met by Mrs. Weston.-- " Very well , I thank you , ma'am .

text: I hope you are quite well .
text_tokenized: I hope you are quite well .

text: Very happy to hear it .
text_tokenized: Very happy to hear it .

text: So afraid you might have a headache!-- seeing you pass by so often , and knowing how much trouble you must have .
text_tokenized: So afraid you might have a headache!-- seeing you pass by so often , and knowing how much trouble you must have .

text: Delighted to hear it indeed .
text_tokenized: Delighted to hear it indeed .

text: Ah !
text_tokenized: Ah !

text: dear Mrs. Elton , so obliged to you for the carriage!--excellent time .
text_tokenized: dear Mrs. Elton , so obliged to you for the carriage!--excellent time .

text: Jane and I quite ready .
text_tokenized: Jane and I quite ready .

text: Did not keep the horses a moment . Most comfortable carriage.-- Oh !
text_tokenized: Did not keep the horses a moment . Most comfortable carriage.-- Oh !

text: and I am sure our thanks are due to you , Mrs. Weston , on that score .
text_tokenized: and I am sure our thanks are due to you , Mrs. Weston , on that score .

text: Mrs. Elton had most kindly sent Jane a note , or we should have been.--
text_tokenized: Mrs. Elton had most kindly sent Jane a note , or we should have been.--

text: But two such offers in one day!--Never were such neighbours .
text_tokenized: But two such offers in one day!--Never were such neighbours .

text: I said to my mother , ` Upon my word , ma'am-- . ' Thank you , my mother is remarkably well .
text_tokenized: I said to my mother , ` Upon my word , ma'am-- . ' Thank you , my mother is remarkably well .

text: Gone to Mr. Woodhouse 's .
text_tokenized: Gone to Mr. Woodhouse 's .

text: I made her take her shawl -- for the evenings are not warm -- her large new shawl-- Mrs. Dixon 's wedding - present.--So kind of her to think of my mother !
text_tokenized: I made her take her shawl -- for the evenings are not warm -- her large new shawl-- Mrs. Dixon 's wedding - present.--So kind of her to think of my mother !

text: Bought at Weymouth , you know -- Mr. Dixon 's choice .
text_tokenized: Bought at Weymouth , you know -- Mr. Dixon 's choice .

text: There were three others , Jane says , which they hesitated about some time .
text_tokenized: There were three others , Jane says , which they hesitated about some time .

text: Colonel Campbell rather preferred an olive .
text_tokenized: Colonel Campbell rather preferred an olive .

text: My dear Jane , are you sure you did not wet your feet?--It was but a drop or two , but I am so afraid:--but Mr. Frank Churchill was so extremely-- and there was a mat to step upon -- I shall never forget his extreme politeness.--Oh !
text_tokenized: My dear Jane , are you sure you did not wet your feet?--It was but a drop or two , but I am so afraid:--but Mr. Frank Churchill was so extremely-- and there was a mat to step upon -- I shall never forget his extreme politeness.--Oh !

text: Mr. Frank Churchill , I must tell you my mother 's spectacles have never been in fault since ; the rivet never came out again .
text_tokenized: Mr. Frank Churchill , I must tell you my mother 's spectacles have never been in fault since ; the rivet never came out again .

text: My mother often talks of your good - nature .
text_tokenized: My mother often talks of your good - nature .

text: Does not she , Jane?--Do not we often talk of Mr. Frank Churchill?-- Ah !
text_tokenized: Does not she , Jane?--Do not we often talk of Mr. Frank Churchill?-- Ah !

text_tokenized: here 's Miss Woodhouse.--Dear

text_tokenized: Miss Woodhouse , how do you do?--

text: Very well I thank you , quite well .
text_tokenized: Very well I thank you , quite well .

text: This is meeting quite in fairy - land!-- Such a transformation!--Must not compliment , I know ( eyeing Emma most complacently)--that would be rude -- but upon my word , Miss Woodhouse , you do look -- how do you like Jane 's hair?--You are a judge.-- She did it all herself .

text: Quite wonderful how she does her hair!--
text_tokenized: Quite wonderful how she does her hair!--

text: No hairdresser from London I think could.--Ah !

text: Dr. Hughes I declare-- and Mrs. Hughes .

text: Must go and speak to Dr. and Mrs. Hughes for a moment.--How do you do ?

text: How do you do?--Very well , I thank you .
text_tokenized: How do you do?--Very well , I thank you .

text: This is delightful , is not it?--Where 's dear Mr. Richard?-- Oh !
text_tokenized: This is delightful , is not it?--Where 's dear Mr. Richard?-- Oh !

text: there he is .

text: Do n't disturb him .
text_tokenized: Do n't disturb him .

text: Much better employed talking to the young ladies .
text_tokenized: Much better employed talking to the young ladies .

text: How do you do , Mr. Richard?--I saw you the other day as you rode through the town -- Mrs. Otway , I protest!-- and good Mr. Otway , and Miss Otway and Miss Caroline.--Such a host of friends!--and Mr. George and Mr. Arthur!--How do you do ?
text_tokenized: How do you do , Mr. Richard?--I saw you the other day as you rode through the town -- Mrs. Otway , I protest!-- and good Mr. Otway , and Miss Otway and Miss Caroline.--Such a host of friends!--and Mr. George and Mr. Arthur!--How do you do ?

text: How do you all do?--Quite well , I am much obliged to you .
text_tokenized: How do you all do?--Quite well , I am much obliged to you .

text: Never better.-- Do n't I hear another carriage?--Who can this be?--very

text: And such a noble fire!--I am quite roasted .

text: No coffee , I thank you , for me -- never take coffee.--A little tea if you please , sir , by and bye,--no hurry -- Oh !
text_tokenized: No coffee , I thank you , for me -- never take coffee.--A little tea if you please , sir , by and bye,--no hurry -- Oh !

text: Frank Churchill returned to his station by Emma ; and as soon as Miss Bates was quiet , she found herself necessarily overhearing the discourse of Mrs. Elton and Miss Fairfax , who were standing a little way behind her.--He was thoughtful .
text_tokenized: Frank Churchill returned to his station by Emma ; and as soon as Miss Bates was quiet , she found herself necessarily overhearing the discourse of Mrs. Elton and Miss Fairfax , who were standing a little way behind her.--He was thoughtful .

text: Whether he were overhearing too , she could not determine .
text_tokenized: Whether he were overhearing too , she could not determine .

text: After a good many compliments to Jane on her dress and look , compliments very quietly and properly taken , Mrs. Elton was evidently wanting to be complimented herself-- and it was , " How do you like my gown?--How do you like my trimming?-- How has Wright done my hair?"--with many other relative questions , all answered with patient politeness .
text_tokenized: After a good many compliments to Jane on her dress and look , compliments very quietly and properly taken , Mrs. Elton was evidently wanting to be complimented herself-- and it was , " How do you like my gown?--How do you like my trimming?-- How has Wright done my hair?"--with many other relative questions , all answered with patient politeness .

text: Mrs. Elton then said , " Nobody can think less of dress in general than I do -- but upon such an occasion as this , when every body 's eyes are so much upon me , and in compliment to the Westons -- who I have no doubt are giving this ball chiefly to do me honour -- I would not wish to be inferior to others . And I see very few pearls in the room except mine.--
text_tokenized: Mrs. Elton then said , " Nobody can think less of dress in general than I do -- but upon such an occasion as this , when every body 's eyes are so much upon me , and in compliment to the Westons -- who I have no doubt are giving this ball chiefly to do me honour -- I would not wish to be inferior to others . And I see very few pearls in the room except mine.--

text: So Frank Churchill is a capital dancer , I understand.--We shall see if our styles suit.--A fine young man certainly is Frank Churchill .
text_tokenized: So Frank Churchill is a capital dancer , I understand.--We shall see if our styles suit.--A fine young man certainly is Frank Churchill .

text: I like him very well .
text_tokenized: I like him very well .

text: " At this moment Frank began talking so vigorously , that Emma could not but imagine he had overheard his own praises , and did not want to hear more;--and the voices of the ladies were drowned for a while , till another suspension brought Mrs. Elton 's tones again distinctly forward.--Mr . Elton had just joined them , and his wife was exclaiming , " Oh ! you have found us out at last , have you , in our seclusion?-- I was this moment telling Jane , I thought you would begin to be impatient for tidings of us .

Elton had just joined them , and his wife was exclaiming , " Oh ! you have found us out at last , have you , in our seclusion?-- I was this moment telling Jane , I thought you would begin to be impatient for tidings of us .

text: " Jane!"--repeated Frank Churchill , with a look of surprize and displeasure.-- " That is easy -- but Miss Fairfax does not disapprove it , I suppose . "
text_tokenized: " Jane!"--repeated Frank Churchill , with a look of surprize and displeasure.-- " That is easy -- but Miss Fairfax does not disapprove it , I suppose . "

text: " How do you like Mrs. Elton ? " said Emma in a whisper .
text_tokenized: " How do you like Mrs. Elton ? " said Emma in a whisper .

text: " Not at all . "
text_tokenized: " Not at all . "

text: " You are ungrateful . "
text_tokenized: " You are ungrateful . "

text: " Ungrateful!--What do you mean ? "
text_tokenized: " Ungrateful!--What do you mean ? "

text: Then changing from a frown to a smile--"No , do not tell me -- I do not want to know what you mean.-- Where is my father?--When are we to begin dancing ? "
text_tokenized: Then changing from a frown to a smile--"No , do not tell me -- I do not want to know what you mean.-- Where is my father?--When are we to begin dancing ? "

text: Emma could hardly understand him ; he seemed in an odd humour .
text_tokenized: Emma could hardly understand him ; he seemed in an odd humour .

text: He walked off to find his father , but was quickly back again with both Mr. and Mrs. Weston .
text_tokenized: He walked off to find his father , but was quickly back again with both Mr. and Mrs. Weston .

text: He had met with them in a little perplexity , which must be laid before Emma .
text_tokenized: He had met with them in a little perplexity , which must be laid before Emma .

text: It had just occurred to Mrs. Weston that Mrs. Elton must be asked to begin the ball ; that she would expect it ; which interfered with all their wishes of giving Emma that distinction.--Emma heard the sad truth with fortitude . " And what are we to do for a proper partner for her ? " said Mr. Weston .
text_tokenized: It had just occurred to Mrs. Weston that Mrs. Elton must be asked to begin the ball ; that she would expect it ; which interfered with all their wishes of giving Emma that distinction.--Emma heard the sad truth with fortitude . " And what are we to do for a proper partner for her ? " said Mr. Weston .

text: " She will think Frank ought to ask her . "
text_tokenized: " She will think Frank ought to ask her . "

text: Frank turned instantly to Emma , to claim her former promise ; and boasted himself an engaged man , which his father looked his most perfect approbation of --
text_tokenized: Frank turned instantly to Emma , to claim her former promise ; and boasted himself an engaged man , which his father looked his most perfect approbation of --

text: and it then appeared that Mrs. Weston was wanting _ him _ to dance with Mrs. Elton himself , and that their business was to help to persuade him into it , which was done pretty soon.-- Mr. Weston and Mrs. Elton led the way , Mr. Frank Churchill and Miss Woodhouse followed . Emma must submit to stand second to Mrs. Elton , though she had always considered the ball as peculiarly for her .
text_tokenized: and it then appeared that Mrs. Weston was wanting _ him _ to dance with Mrs. Elton himself , and that their business was to help to persuade him into it , which was done pretty soon.-- Mr. Weston and Mrs. Elton led the way , Mr. Frank Churchill and Miss Woodhouse followed . Emma must submit to stand second to Mrs. Elton , though she had always considered the ball as peculiarly for her .

text: It was almost enough to make her think of marrying .
text_tokenized: It was almost enough to make her think of marrying .

text: Mrs. Elton had undoubtedly the advantage , at this time , in vanity completely gratified ; for though she had intended to begin with Frank Churchill , she could not lose by the change .
text_tokenized: Mrs. Elton had undoubtedly the advantage , at this time , in vanity completely gratified ; for though she had intended to begin with Frank Churchill , she could not lose by the change .

text: Mr. Weston might be his son 's superior.-- In spite of this little rub , however , Emma was smiling with enjoyment , delighted to see the respectable length of the set as it was forming , and to feel that she had so many hours of unusual festivity before her.-- She was more disturbed by Mr. Knightley 's not dancing than by any thing else.--There he was , among the standers - by , where he ought not to be ; he ought to be dancing,--not classing himself with the husbands , and fathers , and whist - players , who were pretending to feel an interest in the dance till their rubbers were made up,--so young as he looked!-- He could not have appeared to greater advantage perhaps anywhere , than where he had placed himself . His tall , firm , upright figure , among the bulky forms and stooping shoulders of the elderly men , was such as Emma felt must draw every body 's eyes ; and , excepting her own partner , there was not one among the whole row of young men who could be compared with him.--He moved a few steps nearer , and those few steps were enough to prove in how gentlemanlike a manner , with what natural grace , he must have danced , would he but take the trouble.--Whenever she caught his eye , she forced him to smile ; but in general he was looking grave .
text_tokenized: Mr. Weston might be his son 's superior.-- In spite of this little rub , however , Emma was smiling with enjoyment , delighted to see the respectable length of the set as it was forming , and to feel that she had so many hours of unusual festivity before her.-- She was more disturbed by Mr. Knightley 's not dancing than by any thing else.--There he was , among the standers - by , where he ought not to be ; he ought to be dancing,--not classing himself with the husbands , and fathers , and whist - players , who were pretending to feel an interest in the dance till their rubbers were made up,--so young as he looked!-- He could not have appeared to greater advantage perhaps anywhere , than where he had placed himself . His tall , firm , upright figure , among the bulky forms and stooping shoulders of the elderly men , was such as Emma felt must draw every body 's eyes ; and , excepting her own partner , there was not one among the whole row of young men who could be compared with him.--He moved a few steps nearer , and those few steps were enough to prove in how gentlemanlike a manner , with what natural grace , he must have danced , would he but take the trouble.--Whenever she caught his eye , she forced him to smile ; but in general he was looking grave .

text: She wished he could love a ballroom better , and could like Frank Churchill better.-- He seemed often observing her . She must not flatter herself that he thought of her dancing , but if he were criticising her behaviour , she did not feel afraid .
text_tokenized: She wished he could love a ballroom better , and could like Frank Churchill better.-- He seemed often observing her . She must not flatter herself that he thought of her dancing , but if he were criticising her behaviour , she did not feel afraid .

text: There was nothing like flirtation between her and her partner .
text_tokenized: There was nothing like flirtation between her and her partner .

text: They seemed more like cheerful , easy friends , than lovers . That Frank Churchill thought less of her than he had done , was indubitable .

text: Every body seemed happy ; and the praise of being a delightful ball , which is seldom bestowed till after a ball has ceased to be , was repeatedly given in the very beginning of the existence of this .
text_tokenized: Every body seemed happy ; and the praise of being a delightful ball , which is seldom bestowed till after a ball has ceased to be , was repeatedly given in the very beginning of the existence of this .

text: Of very important , very recordable events , it was not more productive than such meetings usually are . There was one , however , which Emma thought something of.--The two last dances before supper were begun , and Harriet had no partner;--the only young lady sitting down;-- and so equal had been hitherto the number of dancers , that how there could be any one disengaged was the wonder!--But Emma 's wonder lessened soon afterwards , on seeing Mr. Elton sauntering about .

text: In another moment a happier sight caught her;--Mr . Knightley leading Harriet to the set!--Never had she been more surprized , seldom more delighted , than at that instant .
